basics.name: Zeyu (Steven) Zhang
basics.label: PhD Student
basics.summary: Third-year PhD student at Northwestern University researching trustworthy AI and large language model alignment. My work spans knowledge leakage detection in complex reasoning scenarios, off-policy learning to rank, and interpretability of black-box models. Experienced in both theoretical research and practical implementation of RL-based fine-tuning methods including RLHF and DPO.

work.name: Northwestern University
work.position: Graduate Researcher - Temporal Knowledge Leakage Detection
work.summary: Developing methods to detect and prevent temporal knowledge leakage in LLMs for prediction tasks requiring temporal reasoning (e.g., legal outcomes, stock performance). Submitted to KDD 2026.
highlights: Formalized temporal knowledge leakage problem and introduced a four-phase detection pipeline
Computed Shapley values to quantify claim contributions and developed Shapley-weighted Decision-Critical Leakage Rate metric
Proposed Temporal LLM Agent architecture with iterative claim verification to prevent leakage
Demonstrated significant leakage reduction across legal case prediction, salary estimation, and stock ranking tasks

work.name: Northwestern University
work.summary: Developed Linear Attribution Mapping Probe (LAMP) for interpreting black-box language models. Accepted as Spotlight paper at AISTATS 2026.
highlights: Developed LAMP framework for interpreting black-box LLMs by fitting locally linear surrogate models
Designed perturbation-based method to probe model sensitivity without accessing gradients, logits, or internal states
Enabled practical interpretability for proprietary LLMs through self-reported explanations
Conducted extensive experiments across sentiment classification, controversial-topic detection, and harmful response auditing

work.name: Northwestern University
work.position: Graduate Researcher - Factual Memorization in LLMs
work.summary: Comprehensive analysis of LLM memorization behaviors under different fine-tuning paradigms (SFT and DPO). Completed as qualifying examination paper.
highlights: Analyzed LLM memorization behaviors under SFT and DPO fine-tuning paradigms
Reproduced and extended findings from Stanford's Finetunebench, evaluating robustness to input rephrasings
Proposed formal distinction between passive and positive memorization, demonstrating superior efficiency of the latter
Designed temporal generalization experiments showing that lightweight system prompts can mitigate temporal overfitting

work.name: Northwestern University
work.position: Graduate Researcher - Unified Off-Policy Learning to Rank
work.summary: Formulated unified framework for off-policy Learning to Rank using reinforcement learning. Published at NeurIPS 2023.
highlights: Formulated unified framework modeling various click models in LTR as Markov Decision Process (MDP)
Proposed Click model-agnostic Unified Off-Policy Learning to Rank (CUOLR) algorithm
Demonstrated effective application of offline RL methods (DQN, SAC, BCQ, CQL) to LTR
Achieved state-of-the-art performance and improved robustness across heterogeneous click models on large-scale datasets

projects.name: Signal Distortion Measurement Device Design
projects.summary: Designed and implemented a high-precision signal distortion measurement device achieving 0.5% error (requirement: 3%) with extended measurement bandwidth of 1kHz-100kHz.
highlights: Applied Hanning window functions to reduce spectrum leakage effectively
Designed algorithm to accurately detect center spectrum by aggregating energy from nearby spectrum lines
Developed LCD interface to visualize data and input analog signals
